What a treat it was getting to see him reprising this iconic adversary nearly twenty years later.

Although the gimmickry is fun from front to back, the ultimate key to the movie's success is its refusal to rest on the easy laurels of those gimmicks. The nostalgic joy of familiar faces is made resonant by the power of Aunt May's shocking death, of villains capable of both goodwill and destruction, of three perfectly unique webslingers bonding over grief, of Garfield's Spider-Man so poignantly stopping MJ's fall, and of an ending that follows "depression is rage turned inward"â€¦

HEAVY SPOILERS:What a joy this was to watch. Fan service in the best way possible. When Andrew Garfield showed up on screen, the theater screamed in unison. When he saved MJ, the theater audibly cried in unison. We were one organism experiencing one of the greatest crossover events in film history.This one had a much darker tone to it, which I appreciated. It dealt with grief and loss and sacrifice. Each Peter Parker sacrificed in his own way,â€¦

The hideous, squealing anti-child of a thoroughly overdosed IP, too busy referencing its legacy and adding newfound context to excuse dubious narrative decisions in past volumes to land any real emotional blow, though they sure do go to drastic lengths to insist this is a serious, dark movie with feeling. Openly aspires to the visual grandeur of Spider-Verse and never, not once, gets there. You are constantly aware that the people who wrote this were told of every joke everâ€¦

Screenplays donâ€™t come up much when we discuss superhero movies, but Spider-Man: No Way Home reminds us that theyâ€™re as crucial as casting and special effects. After their smart, high school-centric scripts for Spider-Man: Homecoming and Spider-Man: Far From Home, both starring Tom Holland as Peter Parker, Chris McKenna and Erik Sommers are faced with a daunting task: maintain the small-scale, adolescent intimacy theyâ€™ve established while also serving up a metaversal, multi-character narrative that draws from the pre-Holland feature filmsâ€¦

If you gave me access to every previous Spider-Man with most of their villains and then told me to make any story with any interaction I wanted - I wouldnâ€™t be able to do it this well. Itâ€™s not perfect, donâ€™t get me wrong; but No Way Home does exactly what it needs to for such a massive idea with a million moving parts, and executes it as well as it can. The final films of the previous two live-action Spider-Man movie franchises both suffered terribly from superhero sequelitis, trying to squeeze in too many villains and too many story concepts. More often than not, when you have two or more villains in these kinds of films, you may as well have no villains, because nobody gets enough screen time to properly establish themselves. An incredible look at just how much great power requires great responsibility. The acting was so, so emotional throughout. The trailer gave hints at what to expect, but I wasn't ready for a lot of it. The villains returning were a nice touch, especially seeing Dafoe cackling and the intimidating Alfred Molina again. We got so much more of Maguire and Garfield than most of us expected. I felt so appreciated to have cameos that were more of supporting characters than bit parts. I was blown away by the performances, the story, the visuals, everything. So refreshing.

Itâ€™s worth pausing for a minute just to acknowledge what â€œSpider-Man: No Way Homeâ€ actually accomplishes. For all its well-documented faults, I still think the MCU is taken for granted in a way that occasionally undersells the ambition with which they handle their properties. For years, Spider-Man as a character has been mocked for getting repeatedly rebooted with new actors to the point where nobody was all that interested in whoever was in the costume anymore. Itâ€™s a major creditâ€¦

Spider-Man: No Way Home captures - more than any other MCU film to date - the marriage of the mundane and the fantastic that characterizes Marvel's version of New York City. At one point in the film, Dr. Strange (rudely!) demands Peter, M.J., and Ned "Scooby-Do this shit" from within the Sanctum Sanctorum's Undercroft. One hard cut later and the ominous sounding Undercroft is revealed as an average brownstone basement. On either side of that cut exist the two seeminglyâ€¦

Although the gimmickry is fun from front to back, the ultimate key to the movie's success is its refusal to rest on the easy laurels of those gimmicks. I was blown away by the performances, the story, the visuals, everything. So refreshing.

Itâ€™s worth pausing for a minute just to acknowledge what â€œSpider-Man: No Way Homeâ€ actually accomplishes. For all its well-documented faults, I still think the MCU is taken for granted in a way that occasionally undersells the ambition with which they handle their properties. For years, Spider-Man as a character has been mocked for getting repeatedly rebooted with new actors to the point where nobody was all that interested in whoever was in the costume anymore. Itâ€™s a major creditâ€¦

Spider-Man: No Way Home captures - more than any other MCU film to date - the marriage of the mundane and the fantastic that characterizes Marvel's version of New York City. At one point in the film, Dr. Strange (rudely!) demands Peter, M.J., and Ned "Scooby-Do this shit" from within the Sanctum Sanctorum's Undercroft. One hard cut later and the ominous sounding Undercroft is revealed as an average brownstone basement. On either side of that cut exist the two seeminglyâ€¦
